title: 104_s2181
content: The Act is titled the "National Grasslands Management Act of 1996" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purpose. The National Grasslands Management Act of 1996 aims to improve the management and administration of grazing activities on National Grasslands by separating them from the National Forest System. This will allow for more effective management by the Secretary of Agriculture while ensuring the protection of various uses of the grasslands. The National Grasslands Management Act of 1996 aims to improve grazing activities on National Grasslands while preserving multiple uses of the lands, including hunting, fishing, recreational activities, and wildlife habitat protection in accordance with laws. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "National Grasslands" refers to areas managed by the Secretary of Agriculture under the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF NATIONAL GRASSLANDS FROM NATIONAL FOREST SYSTEM. Section 11(a) of the Forest Rangeland Renewable Resource Planning Act of 1974 is amended to remove the national grasslands from the National Forest System. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF NATIONAL GRASSLANDS. The Secretary manages the National Grasslands separately in accordance with the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act. Consultation with State and local entities is required for land use policies. Grazing permits are administered in cooperation with grazing associations. Regulations will be promulgated. The Secretary shall promulgate regulations to manage and protect the National Grasslands, considering the unique characteristics and grasslands agriculture under the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act. The regulations aim to facilitate efficient grazing administration, provide environmental protection, and ensure wildlife habitat preservation equivalent to the National Forest System. Additionally, a conforming amendment to the Bankhead-Jones Act authorizes the development of a land conservation program for the National Grasslands to promote grassland agriculture and secure occupancy. The National Grasslands regulations aim to promote grassland agriculture, prevent soil erosion, protect natural resources, wildlife, and recreational opportunities. Hunting, fishing, and recreational activities are allowed, and valid existing rights are preserved. The National Grasslands regulations preserve valid existing rights, reservations, agreements, and authorizations. Fees for livestock grazing will be determined based on the 1996 grazing year formula, with the Secretary having the authority to adjust fees for conservation practices and administrative costs.
